medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient developed progressive difficulty swallowing solid foods (but not liquids) approximately 3 months before evaluation, with occasional choking and regurgitation. Symptoms persisted despite a course of omeprazole. A barium-swallow examination showed narrowing of the distal third of the esophagus; the dysphagia had not worsened at the time of the presentation, and the patient was not aware of having lost weight. He also reported a morning cough but no persistent coughing or difficulty breathing.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Intermittent heartburn for several years, asthma in childhood, and three episodes of palpitations of unknown cause.
medical_history.family_history: A maternal aunt had an unknown type of cancer.
medical_history.social_history: The patient lived with his wife and child, worked in a technical field, was physically active, drank alcohol, had a history of smoking (10 pack-years) but stopped 2 years earlier, and did not use illicit drugs.
